days.name: Wednesday 19th February 2020
days.description:
PHP UK Conference is pleased to bring to you four options for a full day of training on Wednesday, 19th February 2020, a day before the conference.

All course options are a full day (9am-5pm) of hands on immersive training with top professional trainers. Tickets include breakfast, lunch and coffee breaks. Please bring your laptop; power and wifi will be available.

**Please Note - an additional ticket is required to attend the workshop day.

We'll have more information on our main conference speakers and talks coming soon.

tracks.title: Registration and Refreshments
tracks.description: Please bring a copy of your ticket either printed or on a mobile device.

tracks.name: Workshop I
tracks.speaker: Tim Huijzers
tracks.title: Getting Started with Event-sourcing
tracks.description: Over the last couple of years, I have heard of Event sourcing but didn‚Äôt really know where to start until I did a tutorial at DPC ‚Äò17. After having some basic information it was time to start a Hackathon and after that something production worthy. In this talk I will try to give the best information to get started and to know some of the problems you can face if you begin event-sourcing, and we'll build a working application and use Docker and React to tie everything together with events commands and projections.

tracks.name: Workshop II
tracks.speaker: Antonio Peric-Mazar
tracks.title: REST easy with Api Platform
tracks.description: We‚Äôll start by creating a fully-featured API in just a few minutes with API Platform, Symfony and Doctrine. The API will support pagination, data validation, access control, relation embedding, filters, and error handling. It will be documented with OpenAPI and will have a nice UI done in React.

tracks.name: Workshop III
tracks.speaker: Mark Bradley
tracks.title: Introduction to Test Driven Development Workshop
tracks.description: Want to ship code faster? Want to work on features over bugs? Want more confidence in your code? You need to TEST ALL THE THINGS. Writing tests before you write code can be an intimidating concept. During this hands on workshop you will learn how to start using Test Driven Development.

tracks.name: Workshop IV
tracks.speaker: Bastian Hofmann
tracks.title: Deploying your first Micro-Service application to Kubernetes
tracks.description: Kubernetes is a very powerful container orchestration platform that is quickly gaining traction and gives you lots of benefits in deploying, running and scaling your microservice web application. But it has also a steep learning curve. In this workshop you will deploy your first application which consists of multiple Micro-Services to Kubernetes and learn how you can use persistent storage and service meshes and set up sensible monitoring and logging tooling.

tracks.title: Lunch
tracks.description: A 3 course buffet lunch will be served in the exhibition hall where you will also be able to network with fellow delegates.

tracks.name: Workshop I
tracks.title: Getting Started with Event-sourcing
tracks.speaker: Tim Huijzers
tracks.description: A continuation of the morning's session.

tracks.name: Workshop II
tracks.title: REST easy with Api Platform
tracks.speaker: Antonio Peric-Mazar
tracks.description: A continuation of the morning's session.

tracks.name: Workshop III
tracks.title: Introduction to Test Driven Development Workshop
tracks.speaker: Mark Bradley
tracks.description: A continuation of the morning's session.

tracks.name: Workshop IV
tracks.title: Deploying your first Micro-Service application to Kubernetes
tracks.speaker: Bastian Hofmann
tracks.description: A continuation of the morning's session.

tracks.name: Pre-Conference Social
tracks.title: Pre-Conference Social
tracks.description: Join us at the pub (location to be confirmed) with the PHP London user group for a pre-conference social event.

days.name: Thursday 20th February 2020
days.description: Thursday is the first day of the main conference. Things will kick off with a morning keynote followed by four tracks of talks throughout the day. During each time slot you'll be able to choose which of the four tracks you would like to attend. There will be 3 cake & coffee breaks, a 3 course lunch, and rolling tea, coffee and soft drinks included. The day finishes with a keynote before we move on to the main conference social.

tracks.title: Registration and Refreshments
tracks.description: Please bring a copy of your ticket either printed or on a mobile device.

tracks.title: Pragmatic Optimism: How PHP Conquered the Web
tracks.speaker: Samantha Qui√±ones
tracks.description: Though it wasn‚Äôt originally conceived as a programming language after nearly a quarter-century PHP stands as one of the most popular languages in the world. Unlike its peers, it was not carefully designed but rather it grew organically under the guidance of a vast cast of contributors. Today, PHP is a serious and capable programming language, and its endurance speaks to the murky place where computer science meets software engineering. Let‚Äôs examine its history, how it got here, and where it‚Äôs going next.

tracks.title: The La(te)st PHP 7 ‚Äî What's new in PHP 7.4
tracks.speaker: Derick Rethans
tracks.description: We are going to look at the new features in PHP 7.4. Join me to have a look at how the type system is strengthened with typed properties and co- and contra-variance of methods, what changes to operator precedence are, and which new features, such as pre-loading classes, have been added.

tracks.title: Messy data != Messy code
tracks.speaker: Michelle Sanver
tracks.description: The role of our API in Switzerland is to consume a lot of data that was not meant for a digital age and to transform it into beautiful output, for one of the biggest retailers in Switzerland. This is a journey of consuming a lot of data and APIs from different sources and in different formats. Some of them made us laugh, some of us got migraines. We built a smooth architecture to consume and output data. I am proud of our architecture that we seamlessly upgraded to keep the latest versions, now Symfony 4 along the way. I want to share with you how we managed to keep this API up to date for over 5 years and the architecture that we use to make it happen.

tracks.title: ATDD Bowling ‚Äì A Practical BDD Workshop
tracks.speaker: John Behrens
tracks.description: We're gonna play a bowling game, and by that we learn how to use the ATDD approach to write a software to calculate the results. ATDD is an approach within the BDD methodology. After this tutorial attendees will describe features using the gherkin language and implement them a test cases using Behat.

tracks.title: MySQL Indexes, Histograms, Locking Options, and Other Ways to Speed Up Your Queries
tracks.speaker: Dave Stokes
tracks.description: Slow query? Add an index or two! But things are suddenly even slower! Indexes are great tools to speed data lookup but have overhead issues. Histograms don‚Äôt have that overhead but may not be suited. And how you lock rows also effects performance. So what do you do to speed up queries smartly?

tracks.title: Serverless PHP applications with Bref
tracks.speaker: Matthieu Napoli
tracks.description: Running PHP used to be as simple as copying files onto a shared host via FTP. What if we could get back to something that simple, but gain in security, performances and scalability as well? Let‚Äôs deploy PHP on AWS Lambda using Bref, an open-source solution for building serverless PHP applications.

tracks.title: In the world of Password123, be someone's #@%^)*!
tracks.speaker: Ipsha Bhidonia
tracks.description: In case the talk title was too subtle, this session deals with ways to improve your security. Today authentication is evolving to keep up with enterprise and user needs. Hardening the authentication can also at times become a hassle for end user. Come find out how can we better secure our applications with multi-factor Authentication, while giving the users the comfort of Single Sign On. Learn about Identity Providers & how Federated Authentication works and dig deeper into the buzz words of the authentication world - OAuth and OIDC.

tracks.title: Lunch
tracks.description: A 3 course buffet lunch will be served in the exhibition hall where you will also be able to network with fellow delegates and our sponsors.

tracks.title: GraphQL API in PHP
tracks.speaker: Drishti Jain
tracks.description: APIs are a trivial part of development. But there are number of challenges that come along right from data fetching to iterating over endpoints. Worry not GraphQL is here to the rescue. Come dive into the world of GraphQL and learn to develop efficient and easy to understand APIs!

tracks.title: Guidelines on Designing for Accessibility in UX Design
tracks.speaker: Christiana Unaeze
tracks.description: One main goal of great UX design is designing products that ANYONE can use. If you are not thinking about accessibility, then you‚Äôre not thinking about the full user experience. Accessibility makes it possible for people with disabilities to understand and navigate well designed products.

tracks.title: Getting Started with Laravel
tracks.speaker: Jason McCreary
tracks.description: Even with the install guide and docs, sometimes it‚Äôs daunting to get started with a new framework. In this tutorial, we‚Äôll install a fresh Laravel project and review each of its core components to provide you a solid foundation.

tracks.title: Coroutine Based Concurrency with PHP and Swoole
tracks.speaker: Bruce Dou
tracks.description: PHP Swoole has gained traction during the past several years. More and more people are interested with started to try PHP Swoole and use coroutine in PHP to build high performance, large scale web services, online game, micro-services.

tracks.title: PHP Generics Today (almost)
tracks.speaker: Dave Liddament
tracks.description: Support for generics is high up many PHP developers‚Äô wish lists. This talk is a deep dive into generics, their benefits and how, with existing tools, we can get the power of generics today

tracks.title: Meet Johnny the Deployer
tracks.speaker: Georgiana Gligor
tracks.description: After working on AI-powered applications for a while now, we applied a lot of the lessons learned in building our own bot. Johnny, our DevOps chatbot, enables the release manager skip the confusing discussions with the tekkies and master the release process. It‚Äôs using NLP, so you don‚Äôt feel like talking to a bot, rather to a teammate. In this session you will learn about the building blocks of Johnny, dive into how each plays its part (pointing out reasoning behind our design decisions), and then we‚Äôll get to do a live demo to see how all fits together. A bot framework is used to pass on information to ‚Äúthe brain‚Äù, which decodes your message using Natural Language Processing, and if it‚Äôs below a configurable certitude threshold comes and asks you for confirmation/clarification. Once the task to be executed is understood, the ‚Äúbrain‚Äù goes on to execute it and hand you over the results.

tracks.title: Refreshment break
tracks.description: Light refreshments will be served in the exhibition hall where you will also be able to network with fellow delegates and our sponsors.

tracks.title: RTFM
tracks.speaker: Jessica Mauerhan
tracks.description: There is a stereotype of programmers as being antisocial and difficult, and unfortunately many of us take on this attitude as if it comes with the job ‚Äì but it doesn‚Äôt have to be this way! I know it from experience, because I‚Äôve been an angry, judgmental know-it-all, and I‚Äôm ready to tell you how I completely changed my attitude and refactored my life.

tracks.title: Mid Conference Social
tracks.description: The conference social is open to all conference attendees and gives you a chance to relax and meet other delegates after a big day of learning.

days.name: Friday 21st February 2020
days.description: Friday continues with the second day of the main conference. Again, you will be able to attend a morning keynote followed by four talk slots throughout the day. During each talk slot you'll have the choice between four different tracks. There will be 3 cake & coffee breaks, a 3 course lunch, and rolling tea, coffee and soft drinks included. The conference will close on Friday with a final featured keynote, a prize raffle from our sponsors, and then on to the evening post-conference social.

tracks.title: Registration and Refreshments
tracks.description: Please bring a copy of your ticket either printed or on a mobile device.

tracks.title: Post Burnout Thoughts
tracks.speaker: Joel Lord
tracks.description: Working in the tech industry can put a lot of pressure on people. Long hours, tight deadlines and a culture of always being connected can easily lead to depression or burnout. Through the sharing of the speaker‚Äôs personal experience, the attendees will learn to help people that might be experiencing distress and stop keeping this subject taboo. 1 in 5 Europeans are dealing with mental illness and the costs associated with this is too high to ignore. Join us to see how you can help to reduce the risks associated with this plague.

tracks.title: Refreshment break
tracks.description: Light refreshments will be served in the exhibition hall where you will also be able to network with fellow delegates and our sponsors.

tracks.title: Killer Docker Workflows for Development
tracks.speaker: Chris Tankersley
tracks.description: Docker is not just about deploying containers to hundreds of servers. Developers need tools that help with day-to-day tasks and to do their job more effectively. Docker is a great addition to most workflows, from starting projects to writing utilities to make development less repetitive. Docker can help take care of many problems developers face during development such as ‚Äúit works on my machine‚Äù as well as keeping tooling consistent between all of the people working on a project. See how easy it is to take an existing development setup and application and move it over to Docker, no matter your operating system.

tracks.title: What I Learned my First Year as a Full-time Programmer
tracks.speaker: Hilary Stohs-Krause
tracks.description: If you‚Äôre a junior developer who‚Äôs ever wondered if joining tech was a terrible idea, this is the talk for you! The road to success is often zigzaggy, and having emerged on the other side, I feel it‚Äôs my duty to pass on some hard-earned lessons.

tracks.title: My app is secure... I think
tracks.speaker: Wim Godden
tracks.description: More and more sites fall victim to data theft, so you probably know what to do to write secure code. But what else should you do to make sure your web stack is secure ? We‚Äôll go through techniques to secure your environment and look at a bunch of tips and tricks to keep your customer data secure.

tracks.title: Build a GraphQL API with GraphQLite
tracks.speaker: David N√©grier
tracks.description: Ever wanted to create a GraphQL API but don‚Äôt know where to start? Come and join us in this tutorial. I will introduce GraphQLite, a framework agnostic library that makes working with GraphQL a breeze.

tracks.title: PHP OPCache, Realpath Cache and Preloading
tracks.speaker: Jachim Coudenys
tracks.description: Everybody wants quick applications. A lot of that speed can be gained by the way you write your software, but a big chunk has to do with the way PHP is configured.

tracks.title: Testing Legacy Code: Safe Refactoring
tracks.speaker: Katy Eriera
tracks.description: I can't test this code because it's legacy. I need to update the code to make it testable. How can I manage that, without breaking existing functionality? I'll need to write some tests, but... argh!

tracks.title: Lunch
tracks.description: A 3 course buffet lunch will be served in the exhibition hall where you will also be able to network with fellow delegates and our sponsors.

tracks.title: Introduction to Time Series
tracks.speaker: David McKay
tracks.bio: David is a Developer Advocate ü•ë for InfluxData, the company behind InfluxDB. As a serial user group organiser, Cloud Native advocate, and lover of esoteric programming languages, David is always on the hunt to learn and share knowledge with others in fun and exciting ways.
tracks.description: Time-Series has been the fastest growing database category, rated, by DBEngines, for over 2 years; yet, less than 15% store their time-series data in a time-series database. Do you?

tracks.title: Testing Hack with Hammock
tracks.speaker: Riya Dashoriya
tracks.description: Introducing Hammock, a new open source mocking library for Hacklang. Hammock aims to provide disposable interfaces for mocking and spying public, protected, private, and static methods - as well as global functions - without altering their behavior. Using `fb_intercept` under the hood for mocking and unmocking, it also allows mocking of an individual object without affecting other instances of the same class. Come learn more about Hammock and how you can use this to test your code.

tracks.title: Building Modern APIs
tracks.speaker: Rob Allen
tracks.description: Modern applications increasingly require an API, whether to support rich client-side experiences, mobile apps, or to integrate with other systems. This hands-on, practical tutorial will teach you how to build a really excellent and robust API in PHP, based on Slim 4.

tracks.title: Distributed Tracing
tracks.speaker: Billie Thompson
tracks.description: Have you ever lost a request? You see it going into your system but can't see where it's gone or what happened to it? In this talk I am going to show you how to fix the problem of tangled systems that are hard to see through using distributed tracing, and also give you an insight into the wider context and future of the tooling. Some PHP knowledge assumed.

tracks.title: Refreshment break
tracks.description: Light refreshments will be served in the exhibition hall where you will also be able to network with fellow delegates and our sponsors.

tracks.title: Apps, Stacks, and Frameworks: Avoiding ‚ÄúShiny Object‚Äù Syndrome
tracks.speaker: Angel Rivera
tracks.description: DevOps teams are in constant search for magical solutions to their technology woes, but not properly vetting solutions can cause unintended effects. These choices lead to bad design decisions & compound technical debt. In this talk, Angel will share advice to avoid the Shiny Object syndrome.

tracks.title: Post Conference Social
tracks.location: The Pasteur Rooms at The Brewery
tracks.description: The conference social is open to all conference attendees and gives you a chance to relax and meet other delegates after a big day of learning. More details »
